20.text: The Warmun tenement is located within the Halls Creek Orogen (HCO), East Kimberley region

text:
The Warmun tenement is located within the Halls Creek Orogen (HCO), East Kimberley region 
 of Western Australia (Figure 1). Prior to the partial surrender of 12 blocks on 12 May 2006, 
 E80/2866 was 25 blocks in extent, covering approximately 76km2 in area; the retained portion 
 of the tenement comprises 13 blocks covering approximately 42.5km2 in area. Several intrusive 
 mafic  to  ultramafic  bodies,  prospective  for  nickel-copper-platinum  group  elements  (PGE) 
 mineralisation crop out within the tenement. 
 This  report  describes  the  exploration  activities  conducted  by  LionOre  Australia  (East 
 Kimberley) Limited  within  surrendered  portion  of  the  Warmun  tenement  (grouped  under  the 
 combined  reporting  number  C12/2005),  from  the  grant  date,  17  May  2003  to  date  of  partial 
 The  tenement  is  100%  owned  by  Thundelarra  Exploration  Ltd.    During  2003,  LionOre 
 Australia  Pty  Ltd,  entered  into  an  agreement  with  Thundelarra  to  earn  a  60%  interest  in  a 
 portion  of  their  East  Kimberley  tenements,  including  Warmun  E80/2866,  by  funding  A$5.0

45.text: ultramafic intrusions that collectively range in age from about 1910 Ma to 1790 Ma (Page et al.

46.text: 1995).  The HCO is a well-exposed north-northeast trending orogenic belt approximately 120

47.text: km long by 45 km wide.  The package as a whole is termed the Lamboo Complex and can be

text:
ultramafic intrusions that collectively range in age from about 1910 Ma to 1790 Ma (Page et al. 
 1995).  The HCO is a well-exposed north-northeast trending orogenic belt approximately 120 
 km long by 45 km wide.  The package as a whole is termed the Lamboo Complex and can be 
 divided into three zones (Figure 2).

49.text: The  Central  Zone  comprises  felsic  to  mafic  and  ultramafic  intrusions  within  high-grade

50.text: metamorphic  sediments  and  mafic  units  of  the  Tickalara  Metamorphics,  together  with

51.text: sediments of the Koongie Park Formation to the south.  The Central Zone contains numerous

52.text: nickel-copper and platinum group elements occurrences associated with the intrusive suites.

53.text: The  Eastern  Zone  comprises  Halls  Creek  Group  sediments  of  the  Olympio  and  Biscay

54.text: formation,  broadly  correlated  in  age  with  the  c.1865ma  Tickalara  Metamorphics.    These  are

55.text: intruded by the mafic to ultramafic Woodward Dolerite.  The Eastern Zone has a number of

57.text: The  Western  Zone  comprises  granitic  and  gabbroic  rock  of  the  Paperbark  Supersuite  (1865-

58.text: 1850Ma) with the Whitewater Volcanics cropping out on its western flank.  The Western Zone

59.text: has  a  number  of  nickel-copper  and  platinum  group  elements  occurrences  associated  with

text:
The  Central  Zone  comprises  felsic  to  mafic  and  ultramafic  intrusions  within  high-grade 
 metamorphic  sediments  and  mafic  units  of  the  Tickalara  Metamorphics,  together  with 
 sediments of the Koongie Park Formation to the south.  The Central Zone contains numerous 
 nickel-copper and platinum group elements occurrences associated with the intrusive suites. 
 The  Eastern  Zone  comprises  Halls  Creek  Group  sediments  of  the  Olympio  and  Biscay 
 formation,  broadly  correlated  in  age  with  the  c.1865ma  Tickalara  Metamorphics.    These  are 
 intruded by the mafic to ultramafic Woodward Dolerite.  The Eastern Zone has a number of 
 The  Western  Zone  comprises  granitic  and  gabbroic  rock  of  the  Paperbark  Supersuite  (1865-
 1850Ma) with the Whitewater Volcanics cropping out on its western flank.  The Western Zone 
 has  a  number  of  nickel-copper  and  platinum  group  elements  occurrences  associated  with

8.text: A  regional  gravity  high  of  unusually  large  magnitude  is  present  when  compared  to  other

9.text: anomalies of the Australian continent, with only the Giles Complex of the Musgrave Block of

10.text: comparable intensity (Hoatson and Blake  2000).  This is interpreted to be related to  mantle-

11.text: derived magma pooled at or near the crust-mantle boundary.  The various intrusions within the

text:
A  regional  gravity  high  of  unusually  large  magnitude  is  present  when  compared  to  other 
 anomalies of the Australian continent, with only the Giles Complex of the Musgrave Block of 
 comparable intensity (Hoatson and Blake  2000).  This is interpreted to be related to  mantle-
 derived magma pooled at or near the crust-mantle boundary.  The various intrusions within the

14.text: variety of forms including sheets, basinal forms, funnels, plugs and multi-chambered bodies.  A

15.text: total of 60 intrusions have been recognized by AGSO.  It is anticipated that as the geological

16.text: knowledge of the area evolves, more intrusions will be identified.

17.text: SHRIMP  U-Pb  age  dating  undertaken  by  AGSO  (Hoatson  and  Blake,  2000)  has  determined

18.text: some  of  the  major  intrusions  were  emplaced  between  1830-1856Ma.    Hoatson  and  Blake,

19.text: (2000) has proposed division of the mafic-ultramafic intrusives into seven groups, at least three

20.text: of which are coeval, plus three other associations and undivided units.  These are listed in table

22.text: Table 3  Mafic Ultramafic Intrusion: Types, Ages and Depths of Emplacement

variety of forms including sheets, basinal forms, funnels, plugs and multi-chambered bodies.  A 
 total of 60 intrusions have been recognized by AGSO.  It is anticipated that as the geological 
 knowledge of the area evolves, more intrusions will be identified.

28.text: The  scanner  data  is  collected  and  stored  on  a  DLT  flight  tape  and  converted  to

29.text: ENVI-compatible image files (16-bit integer, BIL data file with an ASCII header

30.text: file) during pre-processing of the data, carried out each day on-site.  The DBHS

31.text: stores  the  intensity  of  light  reflected  from  the  surface  of  the  earth  as  digital

32.text: numbers  (DN).    The  intensity  recorded  is  the  net  effect  of  the  wavelength-

33.text: dependent atmospheric absorption and scattering, solar irradiance, light scattered

34.text: back from the earth surface, and background voltages from the scanner electronics.

text:
The  scanner  data  is  collected  and  stored  on  a  DLT  flight  tape  and  converted  to 
 ENVI-compatible image files (16-bit integer, BIL data file with an ASCII header 
 file) during pre-processing of the data, carried out each day on-site.  The DBHS 
 stores  the  intensity  of  light  reflected  from  the  surface  of  the  earth  as  digital 
 numbers  (DN).    The  intensity  recorded  is  the  net  effect  of  the  wavelength-
 dependent atmospheric absorption and scattering, solar irradiance, light scattered 
 back from the earth surface, and background voltages from the scanner electronics.

36.text: Preliminary  interpretation  of  DBHS  imagery  comprised  digital  capture  of

37.text: structural  trends  and  form  lines  together  with  the  identification  and  capture  of

38.text: anomalous features and domains. Ground evaluation is required to determine the

39.text: potential significance of the interpreted features.

text:
Preliminary  interpretation  of  DBHS  imagery  comprised  digital  capture  of 
 structural  trends  and  form  lines  together  with  the  identification  and  capture  of 
 anomalous features and domains. Ground evaluation is required to determine the 
 potential significance of the interpreted features.

text:
Historical  stream  sediment  (135  samples)  and  rock  chip  sampling  (6  samples)  was 
 digitally captured and included into the LionOre Australia database. They are included in 
 Appendix 1 and shown on Figure 3.  
 6.2.  Hyperspectral Scanner Imagery 
 6.2.1. Introduction 
 De  Beers  Australia  Exploration  Ltd  was  contracted  by  LionOre  Australia  (East 
 Kimberley) Pty Limited and Thundelarra Exploration Limited to collect airborne 
 hyperspectral scanner imagery over the East Kimberley Joint Venture project area, 
 including  the  Warmun  tenement,  using  the  De  Beers’  hyperspectral  scanner 
 (DBHS) in September 2004. The DBHS is a 96-channel whiskbroom scanner with
